entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 31, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Detroit Tigers @ Kansas City Royals, 11:10a

Summary

It‚Äôs Skubal Day, which is basically a watchability hack: a 14.19 pNERD rocket fueled by 97 mph and a 57 xFIP- makes this the top gNERD on the board. Kansas City answers with Michael Wacha back from the paternity list and a stingy bullpen, plus Bobby Witt Jr. swinging through an 18-game hit streak, so it‚Äôs not a foregone conclusion.

Skubal, the reigning AL Cy Young, brings elite whiffs and strike-throwing that our model loves; Detroit‚Äôs bats add flair via barrels and speed, even if the bullpen taxes the vibe. The Royals‚Äô case is defense-and-relief first and offense second; they catch the ball, shorten games, and lean on Witt while the rest of the order lags. Wacha‚Äôs profile is craft-over-gas‚Äîmodest strikeouts and a league-average xFIP signal fewer fireworks, but his recent run prevention has been steady, which pairs neatly with Kansas City‚Äôs late-inning infrastructure.

With today‚Äôs gNERD spectrum running 5.92‚Äì15.29, this sits at the summit because it‚Äôs an ace at peak powers facing a playoff-chaser that turns contact into outs. If you‚Äôre ranking screens, pick the one where Skubal‚Äôs K/BB theatrics meet Witt‚Äôs streak and see whether Detroit‚Äôs high-torque lineup or KC‚Äôs gloves-and-bullpen tempo dictates the pace.

(A model from OpenAI generated the above text using instructions, the NERD scores, and these sources: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7.)

Milwaukee Brewers @ Toronto Blue Jays, 10:37a

Summary

Reinvented ace vs. aging legend is a pretty good hook: Brandon Woodruff‚Äôs crafty new look meets Max Scherzer‚Äôs guile, with enough bats on both sides to punish mistakes. At 14.54, this gNERD sits near the top of today‚Äôs slate and around the 95th percentile historically, so it merits your primary screen.

Woodruff‚Äôs pNERD (8.01) is earned: his xFIP- of 78 points to real run-prevention skill, and he‚Äôs rebuilt the arsenal post-surgery‚Äîless slider, more cutter, plus a 93 mph four-seamer that‚Äôs driving elite whiffs despite the velocity dip. Scherzer‚Äôs pNERD (3.42) trails; the xFIP- (107) says league-average-ish, and his season has been managed around a nagging thumb that‚Äôs trimmed pitch counts, though he still profiles tough on righties by track record.

The team side helps the watchability math: Milwaukee‚Äôs tNERD (9.86) is powered by real on-field action‚Äîplus baserunning, defense, and a bullpen that can shorten games‚Äîagainst a Toronto club with a productive core (Guerrero Jr., Bichette, Springer) and strong gloves (tNERD 7.80), but a relief corps thinned by injuries. Add the confirmed matchup‚ÄîWoodruff vs. Scherzer‚Äîand you‚Äôve got star power with contrasting methods: Woodruff‚Äôs model-friendly precision against Scherzer‚Äôs experience and edge-of-the-knife sequencing.

Texas Rangers @ Athletics, 1:05p

Summary

Top-shelf watchability here: a 14.11 gNERD puts this in today‚Äôs upper tier and near the historic 95th percentile, with Jacob deGrom meeting a lively A‚Äôs lineup in hitter-leaning West Sacramento. DeGrom already silenced the A‚Äôs for six scoreless back in April, and he‚Äôs doing it now with 97 mph fastballs and a consciously dialed‚Äëback approach post‚ÄìTJ rather than pure max effort.

The pNERD edge is real (deGrom 9.82 vs. Ginn 5.72): deGrom‚Äôs 97+ velocity and strong xFIP- (78) match the eye test, while J.T. Ginn is the volatile counter‚Äîmessy surface results at home but a legitimately sharp underlying xFIP vs. righties in the mid‚Äë2s that can bite Texas‚Äô right-handed bats. The tNERD contrast fuels entertainment: Texas pairs plus baserunning with elite defense, whereas the A‚Äôs bring youth and power with error‚Äëprone gloves‚Äîgreat for traffic, ties, and lead changes.

Context helps, too: Sutter Health Park has played more offense‚Äëfriendly than Oakland, and the A‚Äôs bats have been lively; if ROY hopeful Nick Kurtz is back after a clean oblique MRI, add more left‚Äëhanded thunder. With Corey Seager sidelined after an appendectomy, deGrom may need to carry a bit more of the load‚Äîfortunately, that‚Äôs sort of his thing.

Atlanta Braves @ Philadelphia Phillies, 4:10p

Summary

Two power arms and one must-see splitter push this into appointment viewing: a gNERD 14 lands near today‚Äôs upper tier, and both starters bring swing-and-miss with real stakes attached. With Zack Wheeler sidelined, Philadelphia hands the ball to Jes√∫s Luzardo, fresh off a 12-K exclamation point and a string of quality starts; Atlanta counters with rookie Hurston Waldrep, whose cartoonish splitter has become the pitch you tell friends about.

The NERD split explains the watchability: Phillies‚Äô robust tNERD (8.48) reflects an entertaining brand built on plus defense and aggressive baserunning‚ÄîTrea Turner and Bryson Stott push the action while the lineup surrounding Kyle Schwarber and Bryce Harper supplies damage. Meanwhile, Luzardo‚Äôs recent form (velo up, whiffs back) and top-quartile pNERD make it a good test for a Braves offense that‚Äôs been more ordinary than its reputation this season.

Waldrep‚Äôs pNERD rides that splitter‚Äîlow spin, big fade, and whiff rates that turn at-bats into events‚Äîplus a firmer mix that‚Äôs helped him throw more strikes since his recall. If he lands the supporting pitches, hitters must honor multiple planes and the split becomes unfair. Philadelphia‚Äôs bullpen volatility has been sanded down by the trade for Jhoan Dur√°n, so leads late are more likely to stick; Atlanta‚Äôs relief corps has shuffled pieces lately.

Arizona Diamondbacks @ Los Angeles Dodgers, 1:10p

Summary

Yoshinobu Yamamoto‚Äôs precision (pNERD 8.21, elite xFIP- 77) meets a D‚Äëbacks club that runs well and has quietly handled him before‚Äîthis is the kind of taut matchup that rewards patience. With a gNERD of 12.63‚Äîwell above today‚Äôs average and near the historic 75th percentile‚Äîthe late innings should matter, especially with L.A.‚Äôs deep, injury-tested bullpen.

Yamamoto did stumble once against Arizona, then answered with seven scoreless in the rematch; his strikeouts, velocity, and command underpin the high pNERD and give L.A. the on-paper edge. Brandon Pfaadt‚Äôs profile is more mortal (pNERD 4.43, xFIP- 99 with a light swinging-strike rate), yet he‚Äôs 2-0 against the Dodgers this year, so the first trip through the order is sneakily pivotal.

Team-wise, the Dodgers bring the louder watchability inputs (tNERD 7.28 with top-tier barrels and a bullpen that‚Äôs carried weight even as Alex Vesia hits the IL), while Arizona offers speed, defense, and contact‚Äîbut a volatile relief corps that can turn tense into messy.

Arizona just took the last meeting behind timely pop, setting up a tidy rubber match vibe; if Pfaadt navigates Ohtani/Betts/Freeman twice, this one earns its slot on your screen.

Miami Marlins @ New York Mets, 10:40a

Summary

Mets thunder versus Alcantara‚Äôs resurgent heat is a fair trade for your eyeballs. With a gNERD of 12.48, this sits above today‚Äôs average and just past the historic 75th percentile‚Äîwatchable by design, not accident.

The Mets just spent two games bludgeoning the Marlins‚Äî19 runs in one, then 11 in another‚Äîand even set franchise marks with that 19-spot and a month stuffed with homers, so the ‚Äúwill-they-punch-a-hole-in-the-scorebug?‚Äù factor is very real. Pete Alonso recently became the club‚Äôs all-time home run leader, and this lineup hasn‚Äôt exactly cooled since. The team-side tilt in tNERD (NYM 12.01 vs MIA 5.57) owes to New York‚Äôs barrels, baserunning, and even broadcast vibes, making any Mets game feel bigger. On the mound, Sandy Alcantara‚Äôs pNERD is the stronger of the two and the story‚Äôs good: post‚ÄëTJ, the velo‚Äôs back and he‚Äôs coming off sturdy work (7 IP, 2 ER vs ATL; a recent quality start). Kodai Senga remains box-office for the ghost fork, but command and pace have dragged‚Äîwalks and short outings have cropped up since his return. In short: star power plus a roaring Mets offense outweigh middling pNERDs, making this one worth a priority click.

Los Angeles Angels @ Houston Astros, 11:10a

Summary

Two 26-year-old power arms and a lineup makeover make this a sneaky high-watch game: Hunter Brown‚Äôs August heater meets Jos√© Soriano‚Äôs turbo sinker. With Yordan √Ålvarez activated and Carlos Correa back in Houston, the Astros‚Äô order suddenly plays like October, which is bad news for an Angels defense that grades near the bottom.

gNERD sits at 11.88, comfortably above both today‚Äôs average and the historical median, and it‚Äôs doing most of that work through the mound: both starters carry top-quartile pNERDs (~8.4) with strong xFIP- marks (Brown 73; Soriano 81) and mid‚Äë90s velocity that misses bats without dawdling between pitches. Brown‚Äôs been rolling, capped by a 1.71 August and another turn in this spot, while Soriano‚Äôs heavy sinker/curve mix returns after a brief paternity-list detour.

Team-wise, Houston‚Äôs tNERD edge comes from gloves and a plus bullpen, and the Correa/√Ålvarez bump raises their contact quality ceiling; LA‚Äôs profile is more ‚Äúoccasional thunder‚Äù (barrels) amid weak fielding and relief work. Narrative juice helps, too: Brown formally gets the ball here, not a fill‚Äëin, against a lineup just reloaded by √Ålvarez‚Äôs return and Correa‚Äôs deadline reunion. If you‚Äôre allocating screens, prioritize the pitching duel and the chance to see Houston‚Äôs retooled core stress‚Äëtest Soriano‚Äôs command.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 30, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Miami Marlins @ New York Mets, 1:10p

Summary

High-octane bats collide with high-octane stuff, and the chaos factor is non‚Äëtrivial. The Mets‚Äô thunder (and occasional late-inning heartburn) versus Edward Cabrera‚Äôs video‚Äëgame changeup makes this the day‚Äôs watchability pick. Cabrera‚Äôs pNERD (8.18) tracks with the skills: an 86 xFIP- and upper‚Äë90s heat, plus the party trick 96.5 mph changeup; he just punched out 10 over seven scoreless in his last start, so the stuff is very live. Peterson‚Äôs pNERD is a notch lower (5.91) but supported by run‚Äëprevention indicators (FIP- in the low‚Äë80s, xFIP- around mid‚Äë80s) and a demonstrated ceiling ‚Äî he spun a complete‚Äëgame shutout in June. The Mets‚Äô tNERD (11.60) does the heavy lifting for gNERD 15.64, and you saw why: they just hung 19 in a record-setting bludgeoning of these Marlins, with Soto, Nimmo, Alonso and friends all leaving dents. Miami‚Äôs tNERD (5.60) is middling, but Cabrera‚Äôs whiffs keep the floor high while their iffy bullpen keeps the drama higher. Meanwhile, the Mets‚Äô revamped pen can still veer from elite to volatile, which is watchable in its own way. Relative to today‚Äôs slate and even historic distributions, this sits near the top ‚Äî premium stuff, star bats, and real chances for weirdness.

Milwaukee Brewers @ Toronto Blue Jays, 12:07p

Summary

Speed, gloves, and two contrasting aces-by-approach make this a worthy watch. With a gNERD of 14.69‚Äînear the top of today‚Äôs slate and around the historic 95th percentile‚Äîexpect action between pitches, not just walks and wall scrapers. Milwaukee‚Äôs baserunning and defense-driven tNERD collide with Toronto‚Äôs slick run prevention while Bo Bichette (13-game hit streak) and Brice Turang (12) keep the contact meter running. Priester‚Äôs profile is quietly sturdy (xFIP- 94) and fast-paced (16.8s), and the Brewers have ridden his starts to 15 straight team wins; a minor midweek wrist scare cleared for him to take the ball. On the other side, Gausman‚Äôs underlying signals remain strong (xFIP- 93 with plus strike and whiff rates), even if August results tilted uneven; the splitter still misses bats. Bullpen volatility adds spice: closer Trevor Megill is on the IL, likely pushing Abner Uribe into the ninth, while Milwaukee also expects Jackson Chourio back, injecting top-end speed and defense.

Seattle Mariners @ Cleveland Guardians, 4:15p

Summary

Gilbert‚Äôs splitter vs. Cleveland‚Äôs gloves-and-bullpen act ‚Äî this is top-tier watchability today. A gNERD of 13.22 plus one true frontline arm is a fine reason to park here.

Logan Gilbert‚Äôs pNERD is the day‚Äôs headliner, and the model agrees with the eyes: a 59 xFIP- with power strikes, fresh off a career-best 13 K gem that showcased the splitter he‚Äôs leaned into this year. Gavin Williams brings upper-90s heat and the wild-card factor ‚Äî he flirted with a no-hitter on August 6, then walked four in 3.1 innings his last time out; the pitch quality is real, the strike-throwing less so. Seattle‚Äôs side of the watchability ledger is offense-forward (top-10 by wRC+), light on the leather, which pairs neatly with Cleveland‚Äôs profile: run prevention via defense and a still-formidable bullpen even without its usual closer. The mismatch comes at the plate, where the Guardians have lived near the bottom of MLB by wRC+ and barrel rate, so Williams likely needs to keep it in the zone to match Gilbert‚Äôs efficiency. Expect a strikeout-forward game that tightens late, where Cleveland‚Äôs relief depth and Seattle‚Äôs shaky fielding could nudge the outcome after the starters exit.

Atlanta Braves @ Philadelphia Phillies, 3:05p

Summary

Cristopher S√°nchez‚Äôs top-shelf indicators meet a Chris Sale comeback, giving this one real appointment-TV vibes. Between an NL East leader humming along and a Cy-worthy lefty reappearing, this gNERD 12.72 tilt has both quality and plot. Philadelphia‚Äôs side carries the watchability: a robust 8.37 tNERD fueled by plus baserunning and a deep order that just toggled from a seven-homer bludgeoning to a 2-1 squeeze, with Kyle Schwarber coming off a four-homer game for extra sizzle. S√°nchez brings a 9.07 pNERD that matches the model‚Äîhe‚Äôs living in the mid-2s by xFIP with elite K-BB splits, particularly at home, so there‚Äôs real swing-and-miss with strike-throwing to boot. Atlanta‚Äôs tNERD (2.99) drags thanks to shaky baserunning and bullpen metrics, so the Braves‚Äô contribution to watchability likely hinges on Sale‚Äôs return off the IL; novelty points matter, and his pre-injury run still looked like a front-line arm. Relative to today‚Äôs slate (avg gNERD 10.91; range 4.92‚Äì15.64) and historically (top quartile kicks in around 12.00), this sits comfortably in the ‚Äúprioritize‚Äù bucket‚ÄîS√°nchez‚Äôs skills plus a marquee activation beat a merely average matchup almost every time.

New York Yankees @ Chicago White Sox, 4:10p

Summary

Two rookies with very different calling cards make this worth a look: the Yankees‚Äô 100-mph upstart Cam Schlittler versus the White Sox‚Äôs Rule 5 changeup craftsman Shane Smith. Add a Bronx lineup currently pulverizing baseballs and a shorthanded Chicago outfield, and you get high ceiling with medium chaos.

With a gNERD of 12.46, this sits well above today‚Äôs average (10.91) and above the historical 75th percentile; that‚Äôs mostly the Yankees‚Äô elite tNERD (8.88), driven by top-tier barrel rate and a power binge that‚Äôs produced MLB‚Äôs leading home-run total. The Sox counter with a bottom-quartile tNERD (2.62), and they‚Äôre missing Luis Robert Jr. after a hamstring IL stint.

Schlittler‚Äôs pNERD (8.64) aligns with the eye test: a 97‚Äì100 mph fastball, an xFIP- of 88, and a debut that featured seven strikeouts and the seven fastest Yankees pitches this season. Smith‚Äôs pNERD (4.78) understates some intrigue: the former No. 1 Rule 5 pick now leans on a low-90s changeup he throws over 20% with strong whiffs, and he‚Äôs recently logged five scoreless vs. Detroit and eight Ks in Seattle.

If you want loud contact and a live-wire rookie arm, this rates as one of today‚Äôs better watches‚Äîeven if the matchup tilts pinstriped.

Texas Rangers @ Athletics, 7:05p

Summary

Rookie mystery vs. veteran certainty: the A‚Äôs hand a debut to Mason Barnett, and the Rangers counter with trade-deadline addition Merrill Kelly, fresh off seven scoreless. With a gNERD of 11.32 (above today‚Äôs average), this tilts watchable on stuff and storylines rather than star power alone. Barnett arrives with a power fastball/slider mix and prospect buzz but uneven Triple-A results, the sort of volatility that can swing a game (and a viewing experience) fast; it‚Äôs his first MLB look, so pNERD is a blank slate. Kelly is the stabilizer: a league-average-ish pNERD (5.23) backed by a tidy xFIP- (91) and, most recently, seven shutout frames versus Cleveland after joining Texas at the deadline. Team-wise, Oakland‚Äôs higher tNERD (7.14) leans on real bats and a lot of positive ‚Äúluck‚Äù to unwind, but porous defense and a shaky pen can turn tight innings into circus acts, especially if Barnett‚Äôs command wobbles. Texas‚Äô tNERD (5.26) rides crisp defense and sneaky baserunning, and the lineup‚Äôs been lively despite losing Corey Seager (appendectomy), Marcus Semien (foot), Nathan Eovaldi (rotator cuff) and Evan Carter. If Barnett throws strikes, stay late; if not, Kelly may keep it brisk and tidy.

San Diego Padres @ Minnesota Twins, 4:10p

Summary

A sneaky-above-average gNERD meets real-world intrigue: Nick Pivetta‚Äôs strike-throwing and San Diego‚Äôs starry bullpen square off against newly acquired Taj Bradley, still finding his Twins footing. If you like pitching with contrast‚Äîcommand vs. electricity‚Äîthis is your mid-tier watch with enough plot to keep you parked.

At 10.96, the gNERD sits a tick above today‚Äôs average (10.91) and near the historical median, which tracks with Pivetta‚Äôs underlying strength and San Diego‚Äôs bullpen heft. Pivetta‚Äôs 2025 FIP as a starter sits around 3.20 with a healthy 20.6% K-BB%, and he‚Äôs particularly crisp the first time through (2.30 FIP), a good omen for early-innings pace. Bradley brings premium velocity but far shakier indicators at Target Field; his home FIP is 4.74 and it balloons versus lefties at home (6.03), a pressure point the Padres‚Äô left-handed bats can probe. The matchup is framed by context: Minnesota flipped Griffin Jax to Tampa Bay to land Bradley at the deadline, and his last turn saw the White Sox tag him for seven in five.

San Diego‚Äôs watchability lift is the bullpen‚Äîmultiple All-Stars, top-of-the-league run prevention for long stretches‚Äîwhich pairs nicely with Pivetta‚Äôs efficiency if they‚Äôre handed a lead. That, plus a live road test against a scuffling Twins club, makes this a solid click.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 29, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Miami Marlins @ New York Mets, 4:10p

Summary

A headliner by the numbers and the narrative: a top-of-the-slate gNERD gets the added jolt of a debuting strikeout artist facing an upper-90s prodigy with elite underlying metrics. If you‚Äôre sampling just one, this one blends novelty (Jonah Tong‚Äôs first start) with genuine quality (Eury P√©rez‚Äôs stuff and the Mets‚Äô thunderous bats).

This game owns today‚Äôs highest gNERD and even clears the historical 95th percentile, driven by a big tNERD edge for a Mets lineup that‚Äôs been hammering since late May (multiple regulars at 110+ wRC+ in that span). P√©rez supplies the pNERD heft: his 2025 Statcast line features an xERA around 2.7, a 26‚Äì27% whiff rate, and premium velocity. Tong brings the intrigue‚ÄîMLB debut, 179 K in 113.2 minor‚Äëleague innings with a riding four‚Äëseamer and an upgraded changeup that‚Äôs drawn raves. The Mets just coughed up a sloppy opener, and their catching situation bears watching after Francisco √Ålvarez‚Äôs fractured pinkie, but the bats remain a show. On the other side, Miami‚Äôs offense has been below NL average, putting more weight on P√©rez to shine.

Pittsburgh Pirates @ Boston Red Sox, 4:10p

Summary

If you like your baseball with a capital-A Ace test, this is it: Paul Skenes (today‚Äôs top pNERD) walking into Fenway to face a top-5 offense, plus Boston‚Äôs late-inning buzzsaw. The only mystery is Boston‚Äôs starter‚Äîreports point to either Dustin May or a Payton Tolle debut‚Äîwhich actually adds a little novelty juice.

The gNERD sits at 14.50‚Äînear the top of today‚Äôs slate (5.84‚Äì14.85) and brushing the 95th percentile historically‚Äîbecause Skenes is a show and Boston tends to make shows watchable. Skenes brings upper-90s heat with real skill metrics behind it (xFIP around 3, K‚ÄìBB% >20%, and even better away xFIP ~2.9), and he just spun seven scoreless in his last turn; if you want appointment viewing driven by stuff and execution, that‚Äôs your hook. Boston‚Äôs lineup, meanwhile, ranks top four in runs and can stress pitchers with contact, power, and baserunning, while the Pirates‚Äô bats have lived near the bottom in runs and homers‚Äîgreat for a showcase ace-vs.-lineup contrast.

If Boston goes May, that‚Äôs a variance-heavy foil; if it‚Äôs Tolle, first-look intrigue applies. Either way, the Red Sox can hand it to a bullpen headlined by a resurgent Aroldis Chapman (gas, whiffs, and results) and newly reinforced by Justin Slaten.

Milwaukee Brewers @ Toronto Blue Jays, 4:07p

Summary

Top-of-the-standings sizzle meets rehab intrigue: Brewers‚ÄìBlue Jays sits near the top of today‚Äôs slate, pairing Freddy Peralta‚Äôs bat-missing track record with Shane Bieber‚Äôs second-start mystery. If you like elite clubs plus one ace in form and another testing a rebuilt elbow, this gNERD 13.76 is your shortlist pick.

Both teams bring big tNERDs (MIL 9.7, TOR 8.3), with Milwaukee‚Äôs speed/defense/bullpen blend and Toronto‚Äôs glove work lifting the baseline watchability. Peralta‚Äôs middling pNERD (4.53) undersells the goods: a 26.3% K rate, 3.69 FIP, and 12.6% swinging-strike rate, while the Brewers‚Äô pen has ranked among the best lately, which helps tighten the finish. Bieber‚Äôs pNERD is 0 only because inputs are scarce, not because the stuff is: he punched out nine over six strong in his Blue Jays debut and now makes start No. 2 after a deadline trade and long Tommy John layoff. Add that these are MLB‚Äôs top two teams by record with Toronto owning the best home mark and Milwaukee the best overall, and the stakes feel October-adjacent without the pyrotechnics. For a final subplot, Peralta is chasing the franchise strikeout leaderboard, which could surface on any given whiff binge.

Arizona Diamondbacks @ Los Angeles Dodgers, 7:10p

Summary

Whiffs, star power, and late-inning chaos make this one eminently watchable. With a gNERD of 11.42, it‚Äôs comfortably above today‚Äôs average and the historical median, boosted by the Dodgers‚Äô bats and a sharp contrast between bullpens.

Blake Snell‚Äôs pNERD edges Gallen‚Äôs, and recent form backs it: after four months out, Snell returned flashing velocity and 19 swinging strikes in 5 IP on Aug. 2, then followed with 7 efficient innings last time out; he was just reinstated from the paternity list and lines up here. The Dodgers supply premium run support ‚Äî top-two by season-long wRC+ and among the league leaders in power ‚Äî even while missing pieces like Max Muncy. Arizona‚Äôs offense is solid and athletic (tNERD 5.68), but the bullpen‚Äôs been combustible, with a league‚Äëhigh 40 blown leads recently underscoring the late-inning drama risk. Gallen brings a quick pace and league‚Äëaverage underlying run prevention, and he‚Äôs coming off 6 IP, 1 R with 7 K ‚Äî enough to keep L.A. honest but not immune to loud contact. Add an elite Dodgers relief unit (by performance and personnel, even with Alex Vesia now sidelined), and you‚Äôve got a high-variance, high-entertainment watch.

San Diego Padres @ Minnesota Twins, 5:10p

Summary

High-velo upstart vs. crafty newcomer alert: Zebby Matthews‚Äô pNERD-soaring stuff meets a freshly acquired Nestor Cortes who just resurfaced with six one-hit, scoreless innings. Pair a thumpy Twins lineup (Byron Buxton left Toronto with two homers) with San Diego‚Äôs relief machine, and an 11.36 gNERD lands firmly in the ‚Äúwatch‚Äù bin.

Matthews (10.02 pNERD) is the headliner: the 25-year-old has added real juice ‚Äî sitting upper-90s with elite strike-throwing ‚Äî which backs the model‚Äôs strong xFIP-/whiff components and gives this matchup its ceiling. Cortes (0.92 pNERD) dings the average-pitcher score thanks to a rough xFIP- in the inputs, but context matters: the Padres traded for him at the deadline and he immediately dealt to the Dodgers, with San Diego‚Äôs pen (Jeremiah Estrada, Adri√°n Morej√≥n et al.) slamming the door.

Team-wise, the Padres‚Äô higher tNERD (7.41) leans on bullpen strength and watchable broadcast vibes, while Minnesota‚Äôs modest tNERD (4.38) is buoyed by power that still pops ‚Äî see that 9‚Äì8 homer-fest in Toronto. Relative to today‚Äôs slate, this gNERD sits above average, lifted by the ‚Äúsee-what-the-kid-does‚Äù intrigue of Matthews versus a name-brand lefty reinventing on the fly, and the likelihood of leverage innings where San Diego‚Äôs bullpen can flex.

Atlanta Braves @ Philadelphia Phillies, 3:45p

Ranger Su√°rez‚Äôs watchability travels well: a sub-3.00 FIP and mid‚Äë3s xFIP as a starter, plus one run allowed across 13 innings vs. Atlanta this year, make this matchup lean Phillies. Bryce Elder‚Äôs quick tempo and improved road xFIP add some intrigue, but his home‚Äërun/BB profile against Philly keeps the edge thin and brittle.

With a gNERD of 10.86 ‚Äî above today‚Äôs average and near the historical median ‚Äî this is a solid viewing slot driven by pNERD favoring Su√°rez (5.85 to 4.58) and a sharp tNERD contrast: Philly‚Äôs high‚Äëfunctioning baserunning and decent leather versus Atlanta‚Äôs clunky baserunning and a wobbly bullpen. Su√°rez‚Äôs underlying line (as a starter: FIP ~2.96, xFIP ~3.56, low HR/9) pairs nicely with a lineup carrying the season series and a very public 50‚Äëhomer chase from Kyle Schwarber. Elder‚Äôs road split helps (xFIP ~3.09), but his away HR/9 near 1.75 and 11 walks in 12‚Öî career innings vs. Philly are red flags the Phils have already exploited while taking six of ten. Injuries tilt the vibe too: the Braves are without Austin Riley and Chris Sale, while the Phillies are contending even without Zack Wheeler.

Seattle Mariners @ Cleveland Guardians, 4:10p

Summary

Precision vs. prevention: George Kirby‚Äôs strike-flooding meets Cleveland‚Äôs gloves-and-bullpen ethos, a tidy watchability recipe with built‚Äëin tension. And with closer Emmanuel Clase on paid leave, the Guardians‚Äô usual endgame certainty is wobblier than usual.

At 10.61, this gNERD sits a shade above today‚Äôs average and near the historic median, and the split explains why: a clear pNERD edge for Kirby (7.79) over Logan Allen (3.02). Kirby‚Äôs recent run has tracked like a metronome‚Äîsix innings, one earned his last time out‚Äîand his profile screams watchable: plus velo and elite strike-throwing that trims the fat from innings. Allen‚Äôs the contrast piece‚Äîa quick worker by pace who‚Äôs coming off a nine‚Äërun bruise and has worn some traffic lately, making first‚Äëinning leverage feel real. Seattle now drags genuine star power thanks to Cal Raleigh‚Äôs 50‚Äëhomer season, giving Kirby rare cushion; Cleveland‚Äôs offense, meanwhile, has graded near the bottom all year and typically leans on defense, baserunning, and that top‚Äëtier bullpen‚Ä¶which is thinner without Clase. Factor in Seattle‚Äôs rotation-bullpen handoffs being shakier than advertised, and you‚Äôve got a tidy narrative arc: early Mariners advantage, then a Guardians scramble to shorten the game without their hammer.

Texas Rangers @ Athletics, 7:05p

Summary

If you like a contrast, this is your fix: Oakland‚Äôs suddenly thunderous lineup gets a crack at a big-velocity prospect fresh off his best start, while a crafty lefty tries to navigate a depleted Texas order. It‚Äôs mid-tier by gNERD, but the bats and backstories add juice.

At 9.19, the game sits a tick below both today‚Äôs average and the historical median, mostly because the pNERD duo (2.89) is modest; the A‚Äôs stronger tNERD (7.27) nudges watchability upward thanks to a young, lively offense. entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 28, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Boston Red Sox @ Baltimore Orioles, 10:05a

Summary

Your gNERD leader is a real one: 14.84 puts BOS‚ÄìBAL at the top of today‚Äôs slate and above the 95th percentile historically, and it rides Garrett Crochet‚Äôs ace-level pNERD (11.92) into must-watch territory. Layer in the subplot‚ÄîOrioles without Adley Rutschman and rookie Samuel Basallo catching Cade Povich‚Äîand you‚Äôve got stakes plus experimentation.

Crochet‚Äôs case is skill-forward, not box-score fluff: his xFIP- of 63 and mid‚Äë90s velocity from the model scream bat-misser, and he‚Äôs punched out 8+ in four of his last five starts, fueling a very live Cy push. Boston‚Äôs tNERD (9.06) adds juice via barrels, baserunning, defense and a plus bullpen‚Äîall ingredients that keep innings crisp and leverage high. On the other side, Baltimore‚Äôs tNERD (3.07) is dragged down by gloves and relief work, and with Rutschman sidelined, Basallo‚Äôs rapid on-the-job education becomes part of the watch.

Povich‚Äôs profile (pNERD 5.62; xFIP- 92) is more craft than thunder‚Äîfive pitches, some recent strikeouts, but command wiggle and a rough last turn‚Äîso Boston‚Äôs hitters should test his sequencing. If you like elite vs. developing, ace vs. adjuster, and a team that just locked its top arm long-term taking center stage, this is your appointment.

Chicago Cubs @ San Francisco Giants, 12:45p

Summary

Logan Webb‚Äôs bulldozer peripherals meet the Cubs‚Äô high-octane, defense-and-baserunning machine ‚Äî a near top-of-the-slate gNERD that promises a tidy, high-leverage watch. If you like workhorse ground-ball artists chasing milestones, Webb‚Äôs 200 IP/200 K bid is the hook; if you prefer chaos, Chicago‚Äôs bats and gloves supply it.

At 13.58, this gNERD sits near today‚Äôs peak and well above the historic median, and the why is straightforward: Webb‚Äôs pNERD (9.27) rides run estimators in the mid-2s with elite K‚ÄìBB% at Oracle, the quick pace, and his sinker-slider bowling-ball act; that‚Äôs the spine of the watch. Shota Imanaga‚Äôs pNERD trails (3.91), but he‚Äôs a splitter-forward strike-thrower whose season line is buoyed by command more than contact suppression, with a FIP notably higher than his ERA ‚Äî precisely the kind of tension NERD is built to flag. The matchup tilt is real: the Cubs have produced top-10-ish thump vs righties, while the Giants have run one of the league‚Äôs weakest wOBAs and a high K% vs lefties. If you need storylines, San Francisco just flexed with a Devers/Chapman power show, and Webb vs. Imanaga is indeed the ticketed pairing.

Miami Marlins @ New York Mets, 4:10p

Summary

A top-tier gNERD (12.69) with the Mets‚Äô offense and SNY doing the heavy lifting meets a mound curiosity: ex-closer-turned-starter Clay Holmes versus a Marlins ‚ÄúTBD‚Äù after an injury scramble. Expect grounders, contact, and some chaos rather than a strikeout showcase.

This sits near the top of today‚Äôs slate and around the 75th percentile historically; New York‚Äôs hefty tNERD (11.74) drives it while Miami‚Äôs middling mark tempers it. Holmes‚Äô profile is league-average by peripherals (xFIP ‚âà 4.07, xFIP- ~100) but very ground-ball heavy (~56%), and he‚Äôs yielded just three runs across his last two starts‚Äîenough to make the sinker-watch worthwhile. Miami hasn‚Äôt named a starter after placing Janson Junk on the IL, so you could get opener/rookie volatility on that side. Meanwhile, the Mets‚Äô bats have been cashing innings‚ÄîMark Vientos heating up and the middle rolling‚Äîwhich props up watchability even with modest pNERD. Add in a live series subplot with prized arm Jonah Tong called up, and there‚Äôs extra juice around Queens. If Miami leans on emerging pieces like Jakob Marsee (lively early road line), there‚Äôs counterpunch potential, but the show is Holmes navigating contact while the Mets‚Äô order tries to barrel their way to entertainment.

Arizona Diamondbacks @ Milwaukee Brewers, 11:10a

Summary

This is a team-driven watch, not a strikeout clinic: Milwaukee‚Äôs high-octane baserunning and defense meet Arizona‚Äôs above-average bats, while the starters profile as passengers more than pilots. If you like action on balls in play and late-inning bullpen leverage, this checks the box.

gNERD lands at 10.17‚Äîroughly middle of today‚Äôs slate but a tick above the historical median‚Äîbecause the clubs boost the entertainment value even as pNERD lags. Milwaukee‚Äôs tNERD (9.63) is fueled by elite running (+2.19) and slick fielding (+1.02), and a supportive bullpen (+0.82), a fun contrast with Arizona‚Äôs better bats (+1.06 Batting Runs) and shakier relief (-1.85). Arizona turns to Nabil Crismatt (pNERD 0.00), who‚Äôs been effective in short stints; Milwaukee counters with lefty Jos√© Quintana (pNERD 0.07), so expect contact over punchouts rather than a whiff-fest.

Recent form adds juice: the D-backs just edged the Brewers 3‚Äì2 behind Blaze Alexander and Geraldo Perdomo homers, with Pavin Smith dinged (quad) but listed as likely to go; meanwhile, Brice Turang and William Contreras have carried Milwaukee‚Äôs recent pop.

Net: average starting intrigue, above-average on-field chaos‚Äîthe kind of game where savvy defense, daring legs, and a bullpen decision or two decide it.

Pittsburgh Pirates @ St. Louis Cardinals, 11:15a

Summary

Braxton Ashcraft is the draw; the subplot is whether St. Louis can handle velocity they‚Äôve openly struggled to hit. This grades as a mid-tier watch boosted by a high-pNERD rookie facing a thinned Cardinals lineup.

Ashcraft‚Äôs pNERD (8.93) and xFIP- (85) flag a lively, efficient look, and the stuff backs it: a 96.9 mph four-seamer with a hard slider and curve, plus just one run allowed over his last two outings as he eased through five scoreless before Bubba Chandler finished a combined three-hitter. Pittsburgh has been leaning into that power/strike-throwing template, and Oliver Marmol conceded his club hasn‚Äôt punished fastballs lately‚Äîprecisely Ashcraft‚Äôs lane.

Miles Mikolas (pNERD 1.94; xFIP- 117) brings contact and scant whiffs, with run prevention further pressured by 23 homers allowed and a FIP north of five. If he lives over the plate, even Pittsburgh‚Äôs low tNERD bats have a path.

Team-wise, modest tNERDs (PIT 3.89, STL 5.09) point to defense/bullpens carrying some of the entertainment‚Äîboth grade well‚Äîwhile St. Louis‚Äô lineup depth is dented by injuries (e.g., Nolan Arenado, Brendan Donovan). In today‚Äôs slate this gNERD (9.92) sits near the historical median, but Ashcraft‚Äôs rise plus the Cards‚Äô fastball question nudges it onto your short list.

New York Yankees @ Chicago White Sox, 4:40p

Summary

Yankees thunder versus a thin Sox lineup and a pitch‚Äëto‚Äëcontact starter is the hook; the fun subplot is whether Davis Martin‚Äôs grounders survive in front of MLB‚Äôs top‚Äëslugging offense. On the other side, Will Warren‚Äôs cartoon‚Äëwide sweeper gives this a pitcher‚Äëwatch wrinkle even if the overall gNERD sits mid‚Äëpack.

At 9.91, the game leans on a big tNERD split: Yankees high (8.70) versus Sox low (2.91). New York leads the league in SLG and home runs, and Aaron Judge is active at DH after a right‚Äëelbow flexor strain‚Äîhe just left the Nationals series with homer No. 41‚Äîso the lineup punch is real even if his glove isn‚Äôt. Warren‚Äôs the more watchable arm (pNERD 4.95): his xFIP trend is better than the surface, and his sweeper owns elite horizontal break; he‚Äôs coming off a short, 5‚ÄëER stumble but recently punched out seven in 6‚Öî. Martin (pNERD 3.26) brings command and grounders with a meager swinging‚Äëstrike rate and a tinkered ‚Äúkick change,‚Äù making him more contact manager than bat‚Äëmisser‚Äîexactly the profile New York‚Äôs barrels feast on. Chicago‚Äôs watchability dips further without Luis Robert Jr., who just hit the IL with a hamstring strain.

Atlanta Braves @ Philadelphia Phillies, 3:45p

Summary

This is a Phillies‚Äëtilted watch: Aaron Nola‚Äôs better underlying line meets a top‚Äëtier, hyperactive offense, while Atlanta arrives with newly claimed Cal Quantrill and a lineup missing Austin Riley. With Zack Wheeler out and Nola just back from the IL, the question is whether his xFIP‚Äë edge (88) shows up before Kyle Schwarber or Trea Turner turn this into a track meet.

gNERD 9.0 lands a shade under today‚Äôs slate average, but the Phillies‚Äô strong tNERD (8.13) props it up via plus baserunning, capable defense, and a broadcast that won‚Äôt make you mute the TV. On the mound, Nola‚Äôs pNERD (5.08), strike throwing, and xFIP‚Äë (88) beat Quantrill‚Äôs 1.48 and 114, so the model likes the home side if the skills hold. Nola‚Äôs return opener was a mess, then steadier over six innings last time; Quantrill was added last week and remains contact‚Äëheavy, with 2025 splits that crush lefties but get torched by righties‚Äîless than ideal with Bohm/Castellanos/Realmuto around even before Harper and Schwarber enter the chat.

Atlanta‚Äôs low tNERD (3.31) reflects weak baserunning and a shaky pen, and Riley‚Äôs surgery thins the thump further. If you‚Äôre here for crisp pitching, temper expectations; if you like stars, power, and aggressive running, Philadelphia supplies the watchability even if this isn‚Äôt the day‚Äôs headliner.

Colorado Rockies @ Houston Astros, 11:10a

Summary

Today‚Äôs gNERD sits on the floor, but there‚Äôs a modest hook: Yordan Alvarez is back mashing and the Astros are leaning on Jason Alexander‚Äôs late-summer cameo to steady a wobbly rotation. If you‚Äôre peeking in, it‚Äôs to see whether Alvarez‚Äôs bat and a patched bullpen can protect a slim AL West lead against a Rockies club that grades out poorly across the board.

At 5.21, this is the lowest gNERD among today‚Äôs games and below the historic 5th percentile, thanks largely to a lopsided tNERD split: Houston‚Äôs decent 4.87 versus Colorado‚Äôs -0.85 driven by deep negatives in batting, baserunning, fielding, and relief. Expect balls in play more than whiffs; pNERD is soft on both sides (Freeland 3.51, Alexander 2.89), with xFIP- readings around league-worse-ish 106‚Äì107 and tepid SwStr%, so the outfielders may log the highlights. Probables are Freeland vs. Alexander.

There is story value: Alvarez homered in his second game back after a 100-game IL stint, and Houston‚Äôs bullpen theatre remains live with Josh Hader out and Craig Kimbrel newly aboard. Alexander‚Äôs sinker/change/slider profile has given the rotation just enough competence to buy time. Net: modest watchability unless you‚Äôre here for the Astros‚Äô pennant math, Alvarez‚Äôs return, or the gentle art of contact management.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 27, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Cincinnati Reds @ Los Angeles Dodgers, 5:40p

Summary

Shohei Ohtani on the mound is the draw, and pNERD agrees: he‚Äôs today‚Äôs top arm, even as the Dodgers are still waiting for his first five-inning start. Nick Lodolo returns from the IL‚Äîand he just punched out 11 Dodgers last month‚Äîso there‚Äôs real upset spice if his finger holds up.

With a gNERD of 13.94, this sits atop today‚Äôs slate and near the high end historically; the pitching drives it, with Ohtani‚Äôs 11.65 pNERD (velocity and whiffs galore) versus Lodolo‚Äôs solid 5.99. The tNERD split tracks the eye test: Dodgers‚Äô offense/bullpen grade out well, while Cincinnati‚Äôs bats lag, a trend reinforced by a recent 7‚Äì0 blanking and a rough August at the plate. If Ohtani‚Äôs recent thigh contusion is truly just a bruise, he‚Äôs a full go, but his build-up means the Dodger bullpen could still matter.

Storylines sweeten the watch: Dave Roberts has openly targeted simply getting Ohtani through five, and Lodolo‚Äôs specific matchup success included fanning Ohtani three times in that July meeting. If you want top-tier stuff versus a lefty who already proved he can miss these particular bats, this is your channel-flipper stopper‚Äîeven if the Reds‚Äô low tNERD warns the lineup might not keep pace.

Philadelphia Phillies @ New York Mets, 4:10p

Summary

A spin‚Äërate prodigy versus a cutter reboot: come for the Mets‚Äô new toy, stay to see if the Phillies‚Äô veteran tweak holds up. With a gNERD of 13.82‚Äînear the top of today‚Äôs slate‚Äîthis one rates highly because two top-tier tNERDs collide and one pitcher might actually be a storyline by himself.

Rookie Nolan McLean has been electric out of the gate, debuting with 5.1 scoreless and eight strikeouts, then backing it up with seven sturdy frames; the breaker set is obscene, with a curve averaging roughly 3,300 rpm and a sweeper near 3,000, which explains the early whiff binge. The matchup juice is real because the Mets hit the ball hard as a group (team barrel rate around 10.4% vs. 8.6% MLB average), so contact against McLean should still be loud when it happens. On the other side, Taijuan Walker‚Äîex‚ÄëMet‚Äîhas trimmed walks and leaned into the cutter, but his underlying indicators (e.g., FIP north of five) say the pretty surface line is living a little dangerously. Layer on Philadelphia‚Äôs athletic baserunning and a post‚Äëdeadline, steadier bullpen, plus New York‚Äôs entertainment-forward broadcast, and you‚Äôve got a high‚Äëwatchability clash with contrasting pitching aesthetics and plenty of star bats orbiting it.

Arizona Diamondbacks @ Milwaukee Brewers, 4:40p

Summary

A top-shelf gNERD plus a built‚Äëin chaos factor makes this one worth your eyeballs. The Brewers‚Äô speed/defense/bullpen blend meets Arizona‚Äôs lively bats and leaky late innings‚Äîrecipe for swingy, watchable baseball.

gNERD 13.25 sits near the top of today‚Äôs slate and above the 75th percentile historically, and the ingredients check out: Milwaukee‚Äôs high tNERD is driven by elite baserunning and gloves with a real bullpen backbone, while Arizona brings punch at the plate but a relief corps that too often hands back leads. That‚Äôs not just theory‚Äîafter a walk‚Äëoff the previous game, these teams have already demonstrated volatility in neon lights. Quinn Priester is the cleaner-on-paper starter here: quicker tempo, better xFIP- than his counterpart, and he hasn‚Äôt taken a loss since May 13 while chasing a club record for consecutive winning decisions. Ryne Nelson brings more velocity than whiffs, and even when he exits ahead, Arizona hasn‚Äôt consistently banked those leads‚Äîexactly the kind of dynamic that inflates watchability. If you like pace contrasts, aggressive running, and late‚Äëinning leverage, this game profiles as the day‚Äôs most reliable chaos engine.

Detroit‚Äôs tNERD edge tracks with what we‚Äôve seen: a top-10-scoring offense this year plus real thump, with baserunning value to pressure a shaky A‚Äôs defense. Casey Mize brings an above-average pNERD (5.37) built on a solid xFIP- (97) and mid-90s velocity, and he‚Äôs shown recent bat-missing teeth, fanning 10 his last time out while pushing a double-digit win total. The counter is the fun unknown: 22-year-old Luis Morales, a top A‚Äôs arm whose 94‚Äì99 fastball and sweeping slider headline a four-pitch mix; he‚Äôs been taking his first MLB turns this month and flashing both strikeouts and walks. Layer in the backdrop of the A‚Äôs transient era at Sutter Health Park, which adds a curiosity factor without guaranteeing quality defense behind the kid, and you‚Äôve got watchability baked in even before first pitch.

Boston‚Äôs big tNERD lead is fueled by barrels, defense, and a bullpen that rarely needs rescuing on nights like the last one, while Baltimore‚Äôs tNERD drags with poor fielding and baserunning. Enns is the curiosity: a 34-year-old lefty recently working late innings for his first MLB save since 2021, now listed for a rare start; if his strike% and whiff gains hold, his high pNERD makes sense and keeps this watchable. Cleveland just snapped a six-game skid behind rookie Parker Messick, but turning to Slade Cecconi adds some volatility that bumps the intrigue.

At 11.90, this gNERD sits in the upper tier of today‚Äôs slate, and the split comes through the components: Rasmussen‚Äôs strong pNERD (7.12) rides an 82 xFIP- with mid‚Äë90s velocity, the kind of strike‚Äëthrowing that keeps traffic light; Cecconi‚Äôs pNERD (4.40) is more ordinary, with league‚Äëaverage xFIP, and public models flag contact quality issues (xERA north of his runs allowed, via Savant). Tampa Bay‚Äôs tNERD leans on speed and a robust bullpen, while Cleveland‚Äôs watchability rests on elite defense and late‚Äëinning run prevention, so a close game tilts toward the Guardians‚Äô relief corps ‚Äî Cade Smith just slammed the door in their shutout win. entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 26, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Philadelphia Phillies @ New York Mets, 4:10p

Summary

Today‚Äôs top-shelf watchability pick pits the Mets‚Äô barrel parade against a 96-mph lefty who just blanked them earlier this summer. With Zack Wheeler out for the year, this is also a Luzardo-as-bellwether litmus test for Philly‚Äôs October plans.

At gNERD 18.33, this sits at the very top of today‚Äôs slate and well into the historic elite, and the reasons are obvious: pNERD loves Jes√∫s Luzardo (9.38) for the power/whiff/tempo combo, and he recently spun 6 2/3 scoreless vs. New York; Sean Manaea (7.29) brings command and pace but has battled late-start fade, with the Mets dropping his last five turns. The lineup side juices tNERD: the Mets‚Äô bats (11.82) have been a top barrel-and-baserunning watch, while Philly (8.16) mixes real baserunning value with star thump. If you prefer names to numbers, think Schwarber/Turner/Harper versus Soto/Alonso/Nimmo, with Soto leading the Mets in homers and Alonso the RBI drumbeat.

Narratively, Wheeler‚Äôs thoracic outlet surgery raises Luzardo‚Äôs importance from nice-to-have to tone-setter for a rotation now leaning on S√°nchez/Su√°rez/Nola behind him. That real-world stress layered onto a strength-versus-strength matchup is precisely what makes this one pop.

Arizona Diamondbacks @ Milwaukee Brewers, 4:40p

Summary

A 100-mph upstart versus a playoff-grade lineup is a fine excuse to find the remote. Misiorowski‚Äôs gas plus Milwaukee‚Äôs madcap baserunning against Arizona‚Äôs lively bats and leaky bullpen makes for tense, swing-heavy viewing.

At a 15.23 gNERD, this sits above the 95th percentile of historic games here, and today‚Äôs inputs explain why: Misiorowski‚Äôs pNERD (10.73) leads the slate and his xFIP- (77) plus 99 mph heat promise whiffs and weak contact, with reports noting he lives at triple digits and is already racking 100+ mph pitches at a Greene-adjacent clip. Pfaadt (pNERD 4.42; xFIP- 99) is steadier than splashy and coming off 7 efficient innings last time out, but his contact profile can get loud, which Arizona‚Äôs defense will need to help manage. The Brewers‚Äô tNERD (9.73) is buoyed by elite run game and run prevention‚Äîthink top-tier steals and a deep bullpen‚Äîwhile the D-backs bring top-10 bats but a bullpen that adds late drama. Milwaukee is dinged by absences (e.g., Chourio, Hoskins), yet Yelich‚Äôs August heater keeps the lineup dangerous.

San Diego Padres @ Seattle Mariners, 6:40p

Summary

Cal Raleigh just joined the 50-homer club and Seattle‚Äôs division chase meets San Diego‚Äôs souped‚Äëup, Miller‚Äëboosted bullpen‚Äîthis Vedder Cup installment actually has teeth. With a gNERD of 12.38‚Äîwell above today‚Äôs average‚Äîtwo bat-missing righties plus late‚Äëinning leverage make this a prime channel‚Äëstick.

Cease‚Äôs 97 mph octane and above‚Äëaverage run prevention indicators (second‚Äëhalf K% 33%, August xFIP ~3.9) power his pNERD 7.65, a clear edge over Castillo‚Äôs 5.06. Seattle did add real thump‚Äîhello, Josh Naylor‚Äîand Raleigh‚Äôs milestone night set the tone, but Castillo arrives needing a clean reset after allowing 19 hits over his last 8 innings.

Castillo‚Äôs run suppression tends to travel poorly this year (home wOBA allowed .261 vs .353 away), so if Cease misses bats early, the Padres‚Äô strongest watchability hook becomes their bullpen cavalry, now headlined by 101‚Äëmph Mason Miller. Seattle‚Äôs bats still barrel better than league average, though, so there‚Äôs swing‚Äëand‚Äëmiss theater on both sides.

Padres tNERD (7.31) leans on elite relief and a top broadcast; Mariners tNERD (4.74) rides power more than gloves. With Jackson Merrill on the IL and Seattle fresh off Raleigh‚Äôs history and a standings squeeze, this rates near the top tier for today.

Atlanta Braves @ Miami Marlins, 3:40p

Summary

A rookie buzzsaw versus a rehabbing Cy Young is a fine way to spend nine innings. With a gNERD of 11.91, this leans pitching-first, and that‚Äôs mostly Hurston Waldrep‚Äôs doing.

Waldrep‚Äôs pNERD (10.09) sits near the top of the historical distribution, backed by a 76 xFIP- and mid‚Äë90s heat, plus a brisk tempo that keeps the channel‚Äësurfing impulse at bay; he just spun seven scoreless with seven Ks and is 4-0 across his first four turns, including 6 IP of one‚Äërun ball against these Marlins. Sandy Alcantara‚Äôs name carries weight, his velocity is back, and he set season highs with nine strikeouts and 114 pitches his last time out, but the 2025 version has been more ordinary (xFIP- 106) even as the repertoire tweaks and heavy ground‚Äëball profile hint at upside if the slider behaves.

The team side is less electric (average tNERD 4.43): Miami‚Äôs youth bumps their score while both bullpens grade out as adventure‚Äëprone, which quietly adds chaos equity late. Atlanta‚Äôs lineup is thinner with Austin Riley done for the year, though Sean Murphy‚Äôs return helps. If you like mound cat‚Äëand‚Äëmouse with a nonzero chance of late-inning weirdness, this rates above today‚Äôs average.

Tampa Bay Rays @ Cleveland Guardians, 3:40p

Summary

Shane Baz‚Äôs underlying ace act meets Parker Messick‚Äôs shiny new‚Äëtoy debut, with Cleveland‚Äôs bullpen ready to slam the door and Tampa Bay‚Äôs track team daring the Guardians‚Äô battery to keep up. This grades as a ‚Äúwatch‚Äù because the stuff is loud, the stakes matter, and the unknowns are interesting.

The gNERD sits at 11.84, comfortably above today‚Äôs average, and the pNERD split explains why: Baz‚Äôs 6.45 reflects real bat‚Äëmissing traits ‚Äî a mid‚Äëto‚Äëupper‚Äë90s heater and a hard, two‚Äëplane curve ‚Äî that have produced elite expected results (xERA 2.44, .257 xwOBA, .177 xBA, 31.6% K%) even when the surface line wobbles. Messick‚Äôs 0.00 pNERD just means we lack a sample; his debut was anything but empty: 6.2 IP, 6 K, 1 ER with strike‚Äëthrowing and a legit changeup, the exact profile that can blunt Tampa Bay‚Äôs right‚Äëhanded thump. Team‚Äëwise, Cleveland‚Äôs offense has lagged (bottom tier by wRC+), but its bullpen remains a strength, so runs early matter. That‚Äôs countered by a Rays club that leads MLB in steals, which inflates the ‚Äúfun‚Äù quotient via pressure and chaos on the bases. Add it up: above‚Äëpar gNERD, a bat‚Äëmisser vs. a rookie with feel, and late‚Äëinning reliever theater ‚Äî worth a primary screen.

Chicago Cubs @ San Francisco Giants, 6:45p

Summary

A high-gear Cubs offense/defense meets a name-brand Giants headliner and a patched bullpen; contrast is the draw. Verlander‚Äôs milestone tour plus San Francisco‚Äôs season-long issues vs lefties turn a merely solid gNERD into a worthwhile check-in.

Probables are Matthew Boyd vs Justin Verlander, a tidy power-vs-guile matchup that our model pegs as mid-pack on the mound (avg pNERD 4.1), with Boyd (5.2) edging Verlander (3.0). Boyd‚Äôs watchability is skill-based: a better-than-average xFIP- (96) and command profile, now paired with a first All-Star nod that tracks with his run of quality starts. The matchup slants toward Chicago‚Äôs bats and gloves anyway: top-tier barrels, baserunning, and fielding drive a big tNERD edge, while the Giants have been among MLB‚Äôs worst vs lefties (.611 OPS/.212 AVG). Verlander remains appointment viewing for history‚Äîhe crossed 3,500 career Ks this month‚Äîand he‚Äôs never taken a loss to the Cubs in the regular season, even if the underlying indicators now read more mortal. San Francisco also moved late-inning anchors Tyler Rogers and Camilo Doval at the deadline, thinning the finish if this stays tight. Given a gNERD of 10.96‚Äîabove today‚Äôs average and our historical median‚Äîplus a surging Cubs club fresh off a sweep, this rates ‚Äúclick over during commercials‚Äù worthy.

Washington Nationals @ New York Yankees, 4:05p

Summary

A watchability coin flip: MacKenzie Gore‚Äôs bat-missing left arm (top‚Äëquartile pNERD) takes on the Yankees‚Äô barrel brigade, while 2024 ROY Luis Gil is fresh off a lat‚Äëstrain return and still proving where his strikes live. gNERD 10.57 lands around the middle of today‚Äôs slate (slightly above the historical median), but the volatility is the hook.

New York‚Äôs high tNERD (8.35) is driven by elite contact quality, so any mistake gets punished, and that‚Äôs especially relevant if Gil‚Äôs command wobbles; he‚Äôs three August starts into his comeback and has issued eight walks in 14 innings after a spring high‚Äëgrade lat strain and a 2024 season that led MLB in free passes. Washington‚Äôs tNERD (0.83) is weighed down by light bats and defense, and they may still be without Keibert Ruiz (concussion IL), thinning the lineup. The Yankees‚Äô star power is tempered by Aaron Judge DH‚Äëing while easing back from an elbow issue and not quite at his early‚Äëseason pace, which nudges this toward competitive rather than lopsided.

Gore remains the swing factor: 10.75 K/9 with a 3.69 FIP/3.61 xFIP and a curveball that‚Äôs become a real bat‚Äëmisser. If he locates that breaker, this plays like an upset watch; if not, the Bronx bats justify the tNERD.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 25, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Detroit Tigers @ Athletics, 7:05p

Summary

It‚Äôs Skubal Day, and the gNERD agrees: this is the one you make time for. A slate-topping 17.59 comes from pairing an elite pNERD for Tarik Skubal with two above‚Äëaverage tNERDs in a compact, sold‚Äëout Sacramento setting.

Skubal has leveled up from his Cy season, leading qualified starters in Stuff+ and riding a four‚Äëseam/change/sinker mix that misses bats and limits damage; his 2025 line features elite strikeout and walk rates to match. He just authored seven scoreless with 10 K and 25 whiffs against Houston, the kind of bully-ball that pNERD was built to flag. On the other side, J.T. Ginn‚Äôs sinker‚Äëslider profile is fun in theory and streaky in practice: he‚Äôs punched out righties in bunches but has been far shakier versus lefties, especially at home, a split that tilts toward Detroit‚Äôs left‚Äëhanded thump. Statcast agrees on the shape of the risk: the slider gets whiffs but, when contacted, has played loud; the sinker invites contact that isn‚Äôt always soft.

Add Detroit‚Äôs above‚Äëaverage barrels and aggressive baserunning to the Skubal show, and you‚Äôve got watchable innings even when the bats cool. The Athletics‚Äô big positive ‚Äúluck‚Äù only sweetens the potential for noisy regression.

Philadelphia Phillies @ New York Mets, 4:10p

Summary

This one earns a premium slot because it‚Äôs high-skill meets high-stakes: Cristopher S√°nchez‚Äôs legitimately plus peripherals take on a thumping Mets lineup, while Kodai Senga brings name recognition but iffier indicators. With Zack Wheeler shelved for the year, the Phillies‚Äô rotation depth is suddenly the story within the story.

gNERD 15.93 is propelled by strong tNERDs on both sides, and S√°nchez‚Äôs pNERD (9.48) is the real headline: his 2025 FIP/xFIP have sat in the mid-2s with stout K-BB splits against both lefties and righties, and since June he‚Äôs led qualified starters in run prevention, which passes the smell test for watchability. Senga‚Äôs results have been good on the surface, but under the hood at Citi Field he‚Äôs pairing a walk rate north of 11% with an xFIP around 4.2, and lefties have drawn free passes at an even higher clip, giving Philadelphia‚Äôs left-handed thump real leverage. Add in a divisional race that just tightened because of Wheeler‚Äôs absence, and you‚Äôve got quality plus consequence.

Translation: tune in for S√°nchez‚Äôs sequencing and ground-ball craft against a lineup that punishes mistakes, then stick around to see whether Senga‚Äôs ghost fork can mask the control risk long enough to get through the Phillies‚Äô lefties.

Cincinnati Reds @ Los Angeles Dodgers, 7:10p

Summary

A high‚Äëoctane ace versus a star‚Äëpowered lineup, plus a post‚ÄëTJ wild card, makes this a premium watch. With a gNERD of 14.75‚Äîwell above today‚Äôs average and near the top historically‚Äîthere‚Äôs real substance behind the sizzle.

Hunter Greene‚Äôs big pNERD tracks with the stuff: 99‚Äì100 mph heat, a souped‚Äëup slider, and sharper strike‚Äëthrowing, all translating to underlying run prevention (3.42 FIP) rather than just a shiny line. He also returned from the IL two weeks ago with six scoreless, looking every bit the headliner again. The Dodgers supply the tNERD backbone: a top‚Äëtier offense and deep pen, lately flexed by Shohei Ohtani‚Äôs 45th homer and Freddie Freeman‚Äôs multi‚ÄëHR game as they head home tied atop the NL West. Emmet Sheehan adds intrigue; 13 months off Tommy John, he‚Äôs back in a six‚Äëman setup and has been serviceable with a solid K:BB since activation.

NERD says the watch here is Greene‚Äôs whiffs versus LA‚Äôs patience and damage; Cincinnati‚Äôs low tNERD offense means his margin is thin, and the Dodgers‚Äô bullpen advantage can tilt late. If you like velocity, swing‚Äëand‚Äëmiss, and a lineup capable of punishing any mistake, this one earns your screen.

Arizona Diamondbacks @ Milwaukee Brewers, 4:40p

Summary

Brandon Woodruff‚Äôs remodeled fastball (the four-seamer owns the best whiff rate among starters) meets a Diamondbacks lineup running a 111 wRC+, with Milwaukee‚Äôs baserunning chaos lurking on every pitch. A gNERD of 13.03 puts this in today‚Äôs upper tier and above the historic 75th percentile.

Woodruff‚Äôs velocity is down to ~93, but the cutter/fastball tweak is still shredding bats, which tracks with his strong pNERD; he‚Äôs the draw on the mound. Eduardo Rodr√≠guez brings the other side of the contrast: a modest pNERD (2.66) driven by a below-average xFIP- (107) and muted whiffs, so Arizona‚Äôs watchability leans more on the bats than the starter. The Brewers‚Äô big tNERD (9.72) is built on havoc and prevention‚Äî138 steals, +13.6 BsR, and hefty team defense‚Äîbefitting a club that just ripped a 14-game win streak; that style tends to keep every single in motion. Arizona‚Äôs tNERD (5.76) reflects real thump (Perdomo/Carroll/Marte) but a thinned bullpen‚ÄîKevin Ginkel on the 60-day IL and Ryan Thompson only now tracking back‚Äîcan make late innings swingy. If you‚Äôre prioritizing pitching craft plus action on the bases, and a live chance of bullpen drama, Woodruff vs. Rodr√≠guez is your play; probables are confirmed.

Los Angeles Angels @ Texas Rangers, 5:05p

If you like ace-versus-flamethrower with a side of narrative, this is your watch: Jacob deGrom‚Äôs fully operational Death Star meets Jos√© Soriano‚Äôs upper-90s sinker, and the gNERD knows it. Pitching drives the ticket here (average pNERD 9.11), pushing a gNERD of 12.36‚Äîwell above today‚Äôs average and near the top quarter historically.

DeGrom is back to being DeGrom: an All-Star again in 2025 with a run of 14 straight starts of 5+ innings and ‚â§2 runs allowed, and he‚Äôs been especially stingy at Globe Life (6‚Äì3, 2.11 ERA, 0.92 WHIP in 12 home starts). Soriano returns to the rotation after a brief paternity/restricted-list stint and just held Texas to one run with seven strikeouts in their late-July meeting, a tidy reminder of why his pNERD is comfortably above average.

The teams themselves won‚Äôt sell you‚ÄîAngels‚Äô defense/bullpen sag, Rangers‚Äô bats have underwhelmed‚Äîbut Texas brings plus baserunning/fielding to keep the ball in motion, and deGrom‚Äôs command/velo duel nicely with Soriano‚Äôs pace and heat. The bet is simple: watch for whiffs, weak contact, and a few high-leverage Rangers dashes rather than a slugfest. If you prioritize elite run prevention over fireworks, this one belongs high on your list.

Washington Nationals @ New York Yankees, 4:05p

Hard-throwing rookie vs. contact-management upstart: Cam Schlittler‚Äôs upper-90s fastball and breaker meet Brad Lord‚Äôs sinker/4-seamer cocktail that kills barrels and piles grounders. With a gNERD of 12.10‚Äîabove today‚Äôs average and just into the historic upper quartile‚Äîthis rates as a real watch.

Schlittler (pNERD 8.03) just carried a perfect game into the seventh and punched out eight over 6.2 scoreless, part of a month in which he‚Äôs run a 2.08 ERA while showing the Yankees‚Äô hardest heaters of 2025; that‚Äôs precisely the power-stuff upside pNERD is flagging. On the other side, Lord (pNERD 6.86) has shifted from multi-inning weapon to sturdy starter: roughly 95 with extreme arm-side run, a near-50% ground-ball rate, FIP around 3.6, and a barrel rate well above average‚Äîfewer whiffs, more damage control, which suits Yankee Stadium tension nicely. The lineup contrast boosts watchability: New York just bludgeoned Boston behind two homers apiece from Jazz Chisholm Jr. and Trent Grisham, and their post-break baserunning has spiked to complement top-tier power‚Äîwhile Aaron Judge remains limited to DH as his throwing ramps back up. If you enjoy the ‚Äúcan a contact suppressor thread the needle against a sledgehammer offense?‚Äù vibe, this is your game.

Atlanta Braves @ Miami Marlins, 3:40p

Summary

Two power arms, two different questions: can Edward Cabrera‚Äôs 96-mph changeup keep baffling bats while Spencer Strider halts a homer problem that‚Äôs spiked this month? With a gNERD of 11.75‚Äîslightly above today‚Äôs average‚Äîthis one leans pitcher-forward.

The pNERD edge tilts to Cabrera, and there‚Äôs substance behind it: his mid- to upper‚Äë90s velocity and that absurd changeup headline a season with a mid‚Äë3s FIP, the byproduct of a more balanced mix and better feel for his non‚Äëfastballs. Strider‚Äôs watchability is volatility; after a measured ramp back from elbow surgery‚Äîand stretches where the underlying numbers improved‚Äîhis August has been about the long ball, with seven allowed in 11 2/3 innings. Team-wise, tNERD dings Atlanta more than Miami; the Braves arrive short a middle‚Äëorder bat with Austin Riley done for the year, and their bullpen just lost Aaron Bummer, nudging late‚Äëinning intrigue in the wrong direction. Miami‚Äôs youth-and-stuff profile is the more entertaining side of the ledger, but both clubs‚Äô less-than-sturdy relief groups add a dash of chaos. With a gNERD of 10.55, this sits a tick below today‚Äôs slate average but near the historical median‚Äîwatchable because the components tug in opposite directions. Bibee (projected: 9-9, ~4.6 FIP-adjacent run prevention with a ~3:1 K:BB) is good-not-dominant, and he‚Äôs coming off a start where he yielded four to Arizona; that makes Cleveland‚Äôs late innings the real variable now that Cade Smith and friends are sharing save chances. Rookie Ian Seymour has a pNERD of 0 here only because the sample‚Äôs thin; the intrigue is real: the Rays‚Äô lefty debuted in June, has been a swingman in the majors, and carried a 30%+ K rate at Triple-A behind a plus changeup.

Team-wise, both clubs‚Äô midrange tNERDs hide quirks: Tampa Bay runs well and the pen is sturdy, while Cleveland‚Äôs run prevention leans on gloves and depth‚Äîbut that unsettled ninth adds volatility, and therefore entertainment. If you like contrasts‚Äîmethodical Bibee versus the unknown lefty and a high-leverage coin flip late‚Äîthis deserves a look.

Baltimore lags (3.26), and its back end is thinner after F√©lix Bautista‚Äôs shoulder surgery forced a committee that lately has featured Keegan Akin grabbing five-out saves. Sugano is the baseball reason to sample: the ex-Yomiuri ace just held Boston to one unearned run and has steadied of late with results outpacing whiffs. This one‚Äôs a bullpen-and-storylines watch, not an ace-off: with a low gNERD (7.38) and both starters carrying bottom-tier pNERDs, the entertainment here likely arrives after the fifth inning. Seattle just got its rotation ‚Äúback,‚Äù but Bryce Miller is fresh off the elbow shelf and allowed four in five in his return, while San Diego recalled JP Sears after a demotion and he answered with a quality start ‚Äî volatility on both sides is the feature.

The model says ‚Äúmeh‚Äù at first pitch ‚Äî both xFIP- marks (Sears 114, Miller 118) and modest miss rates explain the low pNERDs ‚Äî but there‚Äôs intrigue if it‚Äôs tight late. San Diego supercharged an already excellent relief corps by trading for Mason Miller, and MLB‚Äôs own write‚Äëup noted that group had been best‚Äëin‚Äëclass over the season‚Äôs first four months; the contrast with Seattle‚Äôs recently overtaxed staff is stark.

For bats, Cal Raleigh‚Äôs power and the reunion with Eugenio Su√°rez give Seattle thump, while San Diego‚Äôs higher tNERD (7.16) plus a top-tier bullpen and competent contact game can grind out runs and shorten games. If you‚Äôre triaging the slate, this sits toward the low end, but close-and-late leverage ‚Äî Padres pen versus a Mariners group still finding its shape ‚Äî could still be sticky viewing.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 24, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Los Angeles Dodgers @ San Diego Padres, 1:10p

Summary

Top of today‚Äôs watchability board and comfortably above the historical median, this Dodgers‚ÄìPadres tilt blends an ace-level duel with late-inning theater. It‚Äôs Yamamoto‚Äôs refined whiffs and command against Pivetta‚Äôs Padres reinvention, with San Diego‚Äôs All-Star bullpen lurking to decide it.

The gNERD is inflated by strong pNERDs on both sides, headlined by Yoshinobu Yamamoto (xFIP- 77; plus velo), whose year-two surge has quieted last season‚Äôs shoulder concerns and earned him a 2025 All-Star nod; the results have matched the skills. Nick Pivetta isn‚Äôt just ‚Äústeady‚Äù‚Äîhe‚Äôs been a legitimate Petco problem, carrying top-10 run prevention and excellent home splits after an offseason move to San Diego and a blistering start that rewrote franchise debut records.

Team watchability holds up: the Dodgers bring barrels and runs even when shorthanded, with recent damage from Freeman and Pages while Shohei Ohtani briefly sat after a comebacker. The Padres‚Äô tNERD is buoyed by a bullpen that‚Äôs both deep and decorated‚Äîthree All-Star relievers (Robert Suarez, Jason Adam, Adrian Morejon) and consistent late-game run prevention make any tight score worth sticking around for.

If you like premium starting stuff giving way to matchup-heavy chess in the seventh and beyond, this is the game‚Äîhigh skill on the mound, competent bats, and real stakes without the slog.

Translation: expect a tidy, low-scoring watch where sequencing and late-inning choices matter. Kelly‚Äôs arrival raised the Rangers‚Äô rotation floor, but Cleveland‚Äôs bullpen edge and Williams‚Äô raw stuff give this a pleasing ‚Äúrun on the margins‚Äù vibe rather than a slugfest.

Come for the Paul Skenes show against baseball‚Äôs least dangerous lineup; stay for the chaos of a debuting Rockie trying to survive PNC. Colorado is skipping Triple‚ÄëA and tossing McCade Brown straight into his first MLB start.

The gNERD sits at 9.61‚Äîmid‚Äëpack today‚Äîbecause the teams drag it down (average tNERD 1.57), but Skenes‚Äô pNERD 11.09 turns this into appointment viewing. His arsenal still hums at 98.2 mph with elite shape, and Pittsburgh has hinted at dialing back his workload down the stretch, so don‚Äôt expect a marathon. The matchup is friendly: the Pirates‚Äô bats are bottom‚Äëof‚Äëthe‚Äëleague by runs, power, and OPS, which is why even a merely competent start from Skenes often looks dominant in the box score.

Brown is legitimately intriguing‚ÄîTJ in 2023, big strikeout rates in High‚ÄëA/Double‚ÄëA this year, but he hasn‚Äôt worked past 5‚Öî and arrives because Colorado just cut Austin Gomber. Expect a quick hook into a rough bullpen. One late‚Äëgame wrinkle: the Pirates weakened their relief corps at the deadline by trading David Bednar and Caleb Ferguson, and results have sagged since. If Skenes exits early, the door cracks open.

Net: watch for Skenes‚Äô precision and velocity; watch to see whether Brown‚Äôs raw stuff plays before attrition takes over.

Chicago Cubs @ Los Angeles Angels, 1:07p

Summary

Kyle Hendricks draws his old team with a pitch-to-contact blueprint that should shove every ball in play toward Chicago‚Äôs slick gloves ‚Äî and Los Angeles‚Äô not-so-slick ones. With Jameson Taillon back and throwing strikes, plus the Cubs‚Äô lineup freshly detonated in Anaheim, this is more stress test than strikeout show.

At a gNERD of 8.93, this sits below today‚Äôs average largely because the pNERD pairing (Taillon 4.32, Hendricks 2.05) tilts modest; the watchability lift comes from a high-Cubs/low-Angels tNERD split. Taillon‚Äôs recent return delivered six efficient innings with his usual strike-throwing tempo, which plays well behind Chicago‚Äôs top-tier fielding and active baserunning. Cubs bats just torched the Angels ‚Äî Kyle Tucker went double-dinger and Reese McGuire grand-slammed ‚Äî a reminder that Chicago‚Äôs barrel rate travels.

Storyline bonus points: Hendricks faces the franchise he fronted for a decade, now tasked with navigating Tucker, Seiya Suzuki and friends while leaning on soft stuff and command. The Angels can still punish mistakes (hello, Jo Adell), but a leaky pen and a rough recent run of homers allowed make late innings feel longer than they should. Mike Trout is back in the mix, though his 22-game on-base streak was snapped last night, a tidy summary of LAA‚Äôs volatility.

Ranger Su√°rez‚Äôs contact-killing efficiency against a low-miss Jake Irvin makes this more matchup watch than duel. With Zack Wheeler shelved for the season, every Su√°rez turn doubles as a stress test for Philly‚Äôs October plans.

Under the hood, Su√°rez‚Äôs profile plays: roughly a 3.0 FIP and 3.5 xFIP with a healthy K-BB rate, while Irvin arrives with road marks around 5.5 FIP/4.6 xFIP and limited whiffs‚Äîexactly the sort of contact this lineup punishes. Philadelphia‚Äôs baserunning chops (and general on-base churn) add entertainment value if they start stringing balls into the gaps, and the ninth now comes pre-shortened thanks to deadline import Jhoan Duran. For Washington, the hook is the kids: CJ Abrams, James Wood, Brady House, and Dylan Crews are here, bringing swing speed and curiosity even if the team-level tNERD (0.83) and defense won‚Äôt help Irvin much. Trevor Rogers is the draw; Houston‚Äôs bats are the wildcard. This is a below-the-marquee watch driven by a crisp lefty versus a lineup that just spent a series turning mistakes into souvenirs.

At a gNERD of 7.88 (below today‚Äôs average), the tilt leans on Rogers‚Äô strong pNERD (7.92) and skills profile‚Äîan xFIP- of 83 with above-average strike rate and brisk pace‚Äîagainst an Astros offense that‚Äôs been punishing anything elevated. Baltimore‚Äôs lefty comes in after an early-year knee scare but recent form and an 8-K outing on Aug. 1 suggest he‚Äôs very much intact. Houston, meanwhile, has thumped its way through the series‚Äîthree first-inning homers and a late Walker dagger were the latest exhibits‚Äîso contact quality will decide how long Rogers‚Äô efficiency holds. On the other side, Spencer Arrighetti‚Äôs pNERD (0.14) and rough xFIP- (134) hint at traffic; if he‚Äôs forced out early, Houston‚Äôs better bullpen (positive tNERD component) becomes the feature while Baltimore‚Äôs weaker pen and defense dim the undercard. A preview note that Rogers has logged one-run starts deep into games lately only sharpens the contrast. Verdict: not premium, but compelling for Rogers vs. a loud lineup with seventh-inning plot-twist potential.

Summary

This is today‚Äôs gNERD floor special, but curiosity has a pulse: Taj Bradley‚Äôs Twins debut after the deadline swap for Griffin Jax meets Yoendrys G√≥mez‚Äôs ‚Äúcan he stick as a starter?‚Äù audition. If pitching-development experiments are your thing, keep a window open; otherwise, you won‚Äôt miss art. Bradley-vs.-G√≥mez is a lopsided pNERD (5.26 vs. -1.25) inside a low-average tNERD matchup, which is why this game‚Äôs 5.50 gNERD sits at the bottom of today‚Äôs slate. Bradley brings mid‚Äë90s juice and age-based upside, with underlying results that are fine-but-not-elite (xFIP living in the low‚Äë4s and notably better vs. righties), and the fresh‚Äëuniform novelty helps. G√≥mez has a thin track record but was stretched out and popped in his first start (5 IP, 7 K vs. DET) and later beat ATL, so there‚Äôs at least variance-based intrigue. The Twins‚Äô biggest entertainment feature is actually the bullpen (a strength by our inputs), while Chicago‚Äôs offense/defense lag. The series has already produced a Royce Lewis grand slam and Colson Montgomery‚Äôs first career grand slam, so a bat‚Äëgets‚Äëhot subplot is alive even if the overall watchability is not.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 23, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Boston Red Sox @ New York Yankees, 10:05a

Summary

If you‚Äôre picking one game, pick this one: today‚Äôs highest gNERD (17.03) meets Yankees‚ÄìRed Sox stakes and contrast‚Äîan ace lefty who misses bats versus a lineup built to dent scoreboards. It‚Äôs also a rubberneck special: Boston has seven straight over New York, owns the tiebreak, and just won 1-0 behind more crisp run prevention than pathos.

Boston‚Äôs top-10 tNERD rides barrels, gloves, and a plus bullpen, and the headliner is Garrett Crochet (pNERD 11.82), whose 96 mph heat and a 64 xFIP- say ‚Äúgood luck‚Äù to a power-first opponent; he held the Yankees to one run over 8.1 IP in June and has allowed two earned or fewer in 10 of his past 13 starts. New York‚Äôs watchability comes from thunder‚Äîthis group just became the first team ever to hit nine homers in a game twice in one season‚Äîyet that same power has masked sloppier edges Boston‚Äôs defense and ‚Äòpen can exploit. On the numbers, a 9.32 gNERD is a tick below today‚Äôs slate average, but the ingredients are better than the composite. Abbott‚Äôs pNERD (4.95) is near the median, yet his year‚Äëover‚Äëyear strikeout rate leap into the 30% range gives him real bat‚Äëmissing credibility even without big velocity, making his starts play up on TV. Crismatt‚Äôs pNERD is 0.00 only because the model lacks MLB sample; he‚Äôs a short‚Äëleash starter built around a fading‚Äëspeed cambio, which likely hands this game to Arizona‚Äôs bullpen early. That‚Äôs fertile chaos: the D‚Äëbacks‚Äô relief group has graded in the bottom quarter by FIP, while their lineup has been top‚Äëfive by wRC+, a split that invites late swings. Cincinnati‚Äôs light tNERD (2.90) reflects a thin bat/ball profile, but their baserunning and Abbott‚Äôs efficiency keep them sticky in close games. Arizona‚Äôs recent walk‚Äëoff, plus Moreno‚Äôs return, adds storyline lift to an otherwise ‚Äúsolid‚Äëbut‚Äënot‚Äëtop‚Äù gNERD watch.
